The problem is, Black families have been having "The Talk" with their children for decades. So whose children is she referring to? Everybody's...if you don't include Black children. 
Growing up they reminded us every year that this country was built on racism. Martin Luther King Jr Holiday and Black History Month was filled with movies, pics and stories of Jim Crow, segregation and slavery. Black people being beaten and killed. Showing our Black leaders that were important to the Civil Rights movement being killed, and our neighborhoods being burnt down. And reminding us of where we weren't wanted, lunch counters, buses, schools and swimming pools. There were a whole lot of other things, all because of the color of our skin. And they didn't leave out younger children, they had racist cartoons as well.
The month didn't used to be a celebration of Black people, it was basically taking racist people down memory lane of the "good ol' times" or should I say "great" in America. So like I said when, "Miss I don't see the problem with the Confederate flag" talks she is not talking to nor including the Black population.

That it also had the tools to undo that (a task which is not complete) can also be true. These are not mutually exclusive premises. Video Title: 'I was upset': Charles Barkley questions Haley on 'racist country' remark
Name: @YesMayhem7
Comment:
Nikki could not bring herself to listen.  That in itself is not a good sign.   Intention does not override decades of racism backed by policy and practice.  She cannot equate an east Indian experience of perceived racism and strategy to avoid it, with the actual hurdles and blockers American's classified as "Black" still traverse.  It's likely her mother did not want her children to think they are seen by society as incapable.  That has not been the perception in the US.  

For us the intentions and stereotypes have been clear.  It's strange Nikki equates telling children racism exists with the actual inability to achieve.  As if hearing about racism is what makes it a reality.   Hear no evil, see no evil, speak no evil does not work here.  At least, not for us.  I knew racism existed when I got off the bus and walked into my classroom to see an image of Sambo on the chalkboard.  There were teachers who were professional and encouraging, and then there were teachers who would go so far as to be verbally abusive and violent.   Strange enough I was removed from class and choked for alluding to a teacher's prejudice.  

India is no stranger to this.  India has its own caste system which is problematic for its own populations classified as a permanent lower class.  That existed when I visited India in 2004.  Watching BBC I saw Brahmin students who strongly believed Dalit's should not join them in university.  This mindset still exists from what I scan now.   This mindset cannot see the trail of destructive policies, practices and their vehicles; settler practices, slave trade, slavery, Jim Crow, sharecropping, eugenics, segregation, housing, farming, massacres, education, employment, commerce, financial, redlining, incarceration, media communications, population.  The list is incomplete.

Both Nikki and Vivek want to analyze, and platform based on their perspective.  Their experience and global diaspora of labor and commerce, mainly upper caste.  If Nikki can't listen, consider beyond her circle, why should I vote against my interests.  The four corners of my family were here before the 1800s.  Our efforts have been devalued, exploited and overlooked for that long.   We've started over again several times.  We all worked hard.  Even in our fortunate gains life requires hard work and the ability to sustain.  In a lifetime you're liable to realize the hurdles with few supports.  The challenges thrown at you that snag the fruits of your work; The policies and practices that tuck hurdles in landownership, home ownership, employment, higher education has been limited.  We have had someone who has fought in almost every war since 1812.  To hear Nikki assert what I deal with and can give account of as inequitable and destabilizing, does not exist is more than upsetting.  It makes no sense.  Nikki is not ignorant of what she says.  She just refuses to speak on our experience.  She'd rather redefine it from her perspective.  She'd rather say it does not exist.

@@Requinix17Slavery was core to how the constitution was written, in so much as it was a big part of the compromises made within it, not merely the three fifths clause but beyond that. The thirteenth and fourteenth amendments were both set against a period where a large part of the country was trying to avoid applying rights to african americans. The justice department was created in that context and largely for that reason.

Segregation was part of the country's structure. And let's not forget, the founders expressed racist sentiments as well, Jefferson was a slave owner to the day he died, and his wealth was built on that.

There is no way to say America wasn't meant to be a racist country, given racism wasn't a concept in that sense at that time, but racist sentiments absolutely existed and were embedded into the system.

Video Title: 'I was upset': Charles Barkley questions Haley on 'racist country' remark
Name: @jeschinstad
Comment:
@@dirtyd33dz84: Norway ended slavery in 1043 when our most highborn man sacrificed his life to protect a pregnant slave. He's the patron saint of Oslo and we celebrate him on May 15th every year. If you can imagine walking from Canada to Mexico, then you understand what it means when people walked from Rome to Oslo to celebrate him. 

USA is a very racist country. Even the non-racist are non-racist in a racist way. Cultures take centuries to change. I know that racism isn't natural. Because my first friend was a refugee from Sri Lanka. We were seven and he didn't look like me and we didn't have any words in common, but we were the best of friends. In those days, seeing people of a different colour was very rare in Norway, but nobody ever told me that he was different. I just didn't know and I had no reason to invent racism for myself. 

I was trained to believe that Christians are better than other people. My family objected, but society told me this. And I was trained to believe that men and women are unequal. My family told me otherwise, but society still told me this. 

We had all the other bigotries, but racism did not exist in my world. And only a very stupid Norwegian _can_ be a racist, because a thousand years ago, we went to Greenland. And we starved to death and froze to death because we thought that we were superior to the natives who thrived in that environment. And we now know that they were Norwegian in origin. Stupid must be stopped in general, because stupid is stupid. 

America is a highly racist country. You can't progress without accepting that fact. But the only way is to be what you _want_ to be and not what you fear.
